Get your work recognized: write a brag document

https://jvns.ca/blog/brag-documents/

There‚Äôs this idea that, if you do great work at your job, people will (or should!) automatically recognize that work and reward you for it with promotions / increased pay. In practice, it‚Äôs often more complicated than that ‚Äì some kinds of important work are more visible/memorable than others. It‚Äôs frustrating to have done something really important and later realize that you didn‚Äôt get rewarded for it just because the people making the decision didn‚Äôt understand or remember what you did. So I want to talk about a tactic that I and lots of people I work with have used!

This blog post isn‚Äôt just about being promoted or getting raises though. The ideas here have actually been more useful to me to help me reflect on themes in my work, what‚Äôs important to me, what I‚Äôm learning, and what I‚Äôd like to be doing differently. But they‚Äôve definitely helped with promotions!

You can also skip to the brag document template at the end.

you don‚Äôt remember everything you did

One thing I‚Äôm always struck by when it comes to performance review time is a feeling of ‚Äúwait, what did I do in the last 6 months?‚Äú. This is a kind of demoralizing feeling and it‚Äôs usually not based in reality, more in ‚ÄúI forgot what cool stuff I actually did‚Äù.

I invariably end up having to spend a bunch of time looking through my pull requests, tickets, launch emails, design documents, and more. I always end up finding small (and sometimes not-so-small) things that I completely forgot I did, like:

  • mentored an intern 5 months ago
  • did a small-but-important security project
  • spent a few weeks helping get an important migration over the line
  • helped X put together this design doc
  • etcetera!

your manager doesn‚Äôt remember everything you did

...

here‚Äôs the tactic: write a document listing your accomplishments

The tactic is pretty simple! Instead of trying to remember everything you did with your brain, maintain a ‚Äúbrag document‚Äù that lists everything so you can refer to it when you get to performance review season!

...

Where I work we call this a ‚Äúbrag document‚Äù but I‚Äôve heard other names for the same concept like ‚Äúhype document‚Äù or ‚Äúlist of stuff I did‚Äù :).

There‚Äôs a basic template for a brag document at the end of this post.

share your brag document with your manager

When I first wrote a brag document I was kind of nervous about sharing it with my manager. It felt weird to be like ‚Äúhey, uh, look at all the awesome stuff I did this year, I wrote a long document listing everything‚Äù. But my manager was really thankful for it ‚Äì I think his perspective was ‚Äúthis makes my job way easier, now I can look at the document when writing your perf review instead of trying to remember what happened‚Äù.

Giving them a document that explains your accomplishments will really help your manager advocate for you in discussions about your performance and come to any meetings they need to have prepared.

Brag documents also really help with manager transitions ‚Äì if you get a new manager 3 months before an important performance review that you want to do well on, giving them a brag document outlining your most important work & its impact will help them understand what you‚Äôve been doing even though they may not have been aware of any of your work before.

share it with your peer reviewers

Similarly, if your company does peer feedback as part of the promotion/perf process ‚Äì share your brag document with your peer reviewers!! Every time someone shares their doc with me I find it SO HELPFUL with writing their review for much the same reasons it‚Äôs helpful to share it with your manager ‚Äì it reminds me of all the amazing things they did, and when they list their goals in their brag document it also helps me see what areas they might be most interested in feedback on.

On some teams at work it‚Äôs a team norm to share a brag document with peer reviewers to make it easier for them.

explain the big picture

In addition to just listing accomplishments, in your brag document you can write the narrative explaining the big picture of your work. Have you been really focused on security? On building your product skills & having really good relationships with your users? On building a strong culture of code review on the team?

In my brag document, I like to do this by making a section for areas that I‚Äôve been focused on (like ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù) and listing all the work I‚Äôve done in that area there. This is especially good if you‚Äôre working on something fuzzy like ‚Äúbuilding a stronger culture of code review‚Äù where all the individual actions you do towards that might be relatively small and there isn‚Äôt a big shiny ship.

use your brag document to notice patterns

In the past I‚Äôve found the brag document useful not just to hype my accomplishments, but also to reflect on the work I‚Äôve done. Some questions it‚Äôs helped me with:

  • What work do I feel most proud of?
  • Are there themes in these projects I should be thinking about? What‚Äôs the big picture of what I‚Äôm working on? (am I working a lot on security? localization?).
  • What do I wish I was doing more / less of?
  • Which of my projects had the effect I wanted, and which didn‚Äôt? Why might that have been?
  • What could have gone better with project X? What might I want to do differently next time?

don‚Äôt forget to include the fuzzy work

A lot of us work on fuzzy projects that can feel hard to quantify, like:

  • improving code quality on the team / making code reviews a little more in depth
  • making on call easier
  • building a more fair interview process / performance review system
  • refactoring / driving down technical debt

A lot of people will leave this kind of work out because they don‚Äôt know how to explain why it‚Äôs important. But I think this kind of work is especially important to put into your brag document because it‚Äôs the most likely to fall under the radar! One way to approach this is to, for each goal:

  1. explain your goal for the work (why do you think it‚Äôs important to refactor X piece of code?)
  2. list some things you‚Äôve done towards that goal
  3. list any effects you‚Äôve seen of the work, even if they‚Äôre a little indirect

If you tell your coworkers this kind of work is important to you and tell them what you‚Äôve been doing, maybe they can also give you ideas about how to do it more effectively or make the effects of that work more obvious!

encourage each other to celebrate accomplishments

the brag workshop: help people list their accomplishments

We did this by running a ‚Äúbrag workshop‚Äù just before performance review season. The format of the workshop is like this:

Part 1: write the document: 1-2 hours. Everybody sits down with their laptop, starts looking through their pull requests, tickets they resolved, design docs, etc, and puts together a list of important things they did in the last 6 months.

Part 2: pair up and make the impact of your work clearer: 1 hour. The goal of this part is to pair up, review each other‚Äôs documents, and identify places where people haven‚Äôt bragged ‚Äúenough‚Äù ‚Äì maybe they worked on an extremely critical project to the company but didn‚Äôt highlight how important it was, maybe they improved test performance but didn‚Äôt say that they made the tests 3 times faster and that it improved everyone‚Äôs developer experience. It‚Äôs easy to accidentally write ‚ÄúI shipped $feature‚Äù and miss the follow up (‚Äú‚Ä¶ which caused $thing to happen‚Äù). Another person reading through your document can help you catch the places where you need to clarify the impact.

biweekly brag document writing session

thanks

...

I‚Äôd also recommend the blog post Hype Yourself! You‚Äôre Worth It! by Aashni Shah which talks about a similar approach.

Appendix: brag document template

Here‚Äôs a template for a brag document! Usually I make one brag document per year. (‚ÄúJulia‚Äôs 2017 brag document‚Äù). I think it‚Äôs okay to make it quite long / comprehensive ‚Äì 5-10 pages or more for a year of work doesn‚Äôt seem like too much to me, especially if you‚Äôre including some graphs/charts / screenshots to show the effects of what you did.

One thing I want to emphasize, for people who don‚Äôt like to brag, is ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to try to make your work sound better than it is. Just make it sound exactly as good as it is! For example ‚Äúwas the primary contributor to X new feature that‚Äôs now used by 60% of our customers and has gotten Y positive feedback‚Äù.

Goals for this year:

  • List your major goals here! Sharing your goals with your manager & coworkers is really nice because it helps them see how they can support you in accomplishing those goals!

Goals for next year

  • If it‚Äôs getting towards the end of the year, maybe start writing down what you think your goals for next year might be.

Projects

For each one, go through:

  • What your contributions were (did you come up with the design? Which components did you build? Was there some useful insight like ‚Äúwait, we can cut scope and do what we want by doing way less work‚Äù that you came up with?)
  • The impact of the project ‚Äì who was it for? Are there numbers you can attach to it? (saved X dollars? shipped new feature that has helped sell Y big deals? Improved performance by X%? Used by X internal users every day?). Did it support some important non-numeric company goal (required to pass an audit? helped retain an important user?)

Remember: don‚Äôt forget to explain what the results of you work actually were! It‚Äôs often important to go back a few months later and fill in what actually happened after you launched the project.

Collaboration & mentorship

Examples of things in this category:

  • Helping others in an area you‚Äôre an expert in (like ‚Äúother engineers regularly ask me for one-off help solving weird bugs in their CSS‚Äù or ‚Äúquoting from the C standard at just the right moment‚Äù)
  • Mentoring interns / helping new team members get started
  • Writing really clear emails/meeting notes
  • Foundational code that other people built on top of
  • Improving monitoring / dashboards / on call
  • Any code review that you spent a particularly long time on / that you think was especially important
  • Important questions you answered (‚Äúhelped Risha from OTHER_TEAM with a lot of questions related to Y‚Äù)
  • Mentoring someone on a project (‚Äúgave Ben advice from time to time on leading his first big project‚Äù)
  • Giving an internal talk or workshop

Design & documentation

List design docs & documentation that you worked on

  • Design docs: I usually just say ‚Äúwrote design for X‚Äù or ‚Äúreviewed design for X‚Äù
  • Documentation: maybe briefly explain the goal behind this documentation (for example ‚Äúwe were getting a lot of questions about X, so I documented it and now we can answer the questions more quickly‚Äù)

Company building

This is a category we have at work ‚Äì it basically means ‚Äúthings you did to help the company overall, not just your project / team‚Äù. Some things that go in here:

  • Going above & beyond with interviewing or recruiting (doing campus recruiting, etc)
  • Improving important processes, like the interview process or writing better onboarding materials

What you learned

My friend Julian suggested this section and I think it‚Äôs a great idea ‚Äì try listing important things you learned or skills you‚Äôve acquired recently! Some examples of skills you might be learning or improving:

  • how to do performance analysis & make code run faster
  • internals of an important piece of software (like the JVM or Postgres or Linux)
  • how to use a library (like React)
  • how to use an important tool (like the command line or Firefox dev tools)
  • about a specific area of programming (like localization or timezones)
  • an area like product management / UX design
  • how to write a clear design doc
  • a new programming language

It‚Äôs really easy to lose track of what skills you‚Äôre learning, and usually when I reflect on this I realize I learned a lot more than I thought and also notice things that I‚Äôm not learning that I wish I was.

Outside of work

It‚Äôs also often useful to track accomplishments outside of work, like:

  • blog posts
  • talks/panels
  • open source work
  • Industry recognition

I think this can be a nice way to highlight how you‚Äôre thinking about your career outside of strictly what you‚Äôre doing at work.

This can also include other non-career-related things you‚Äôre proud of, if that feels good to you! Some people like to keep a combined personal + work brag document.

General prompts

If you‚Äôre feeling stuck for things to mention, try:

  • If you were trying to convince a friend to come join your company/team, what would you tell them about your work?
  • Did anybody tell you that you did something well recently?
